sen.j: 鷹山（たかやま）は、かつて京都の祇園祭に有った山鉾の1つ。
sen.e: Once having a parade in Gion Matsuri Festival in Kyoto, Takayama is a "yamaboko," which is a festival float mounted with a decorative long-handled sword.

sen.j: 応仁の乱以前に起源を持ち、大舩鉾の直前を巡行した大規模な曳山だったが、文政9年（1826年）に激しい夕立に遭って懸装品に甚だしい汚損を被ってしまい、休山していたところに元治元年（1864年）の蛤御門の変による大火で御神体と一部の懸装品を残して焼失。
sen.e: Takayama originated before the Onin War, and it was a giant-float parading the streets of Kyoto right before "Ofuneboko" (a different yamaboko), but in 1826 the ornaments of Takayama got grossly stained with the raindrop of a hard shower, so the float stopped parading, and in 1864, the big fire breaking out in "Hamagurigomon no Hen" (the rebellion at the Hamaguri Gate) burned the float except for some ornaments & "Goshintai" (the object of worship in Shinto).

sen.j: 現在は宵山に限って残された御神体と懸装品が同山の町内で展示（居祭・いまつり）されている。
sen.e: At present, the Goshintai and ornaments that survived the fire are on display in Koromotana-cho just in "Yoiyama" (the pre-parade event), and the display is called "Imatsuri."
